		     }
if stage:number < 1 {

			print "end staging check.".
			print "----------".
		 }

Yeah the problem has plagued us in kOS for ages and we knew it was the main stock game's fault but it's hard to get action on bugs that are discovered by a mod because the presumption is always that the mod *caused* the bug rather than that the mod just made the bug become properly detected and quantified.

History: In the past, kOS did its own homebrewed "how much resource in current stage" calculation, with a complex walk of the parts tree, which meant we had to reverse-engineer how SQUAD made complex things like fuel line hoses work and parts that connect but don't allow fuel (like struts). In so doing we got the feeling that our code was going to be super fragile and break with the next update, just because what the stock game was doing to handle things (especially the weird hack they did for fuel hoses) seemed like exactly the sort of spaghetti design that would be changed later and we were getting too dependent on making assumptions about the inner guts of the data structure - exactly the sort of thing that should be kept private (but wasn't) and masked behind an API intermediary layer. This made us nervous and so we switched to calling SQUAD's own built-in routines to get resources in stage instead of doing the work ourselves, with an eye toward future-compatibility.

This made it so things didn't break when there were massive overhauls to the fuel/resource system in later releases of KSP, which was good, but then meant we "inherited" stock KSP's bugs in how it is calculating the stage resources. In other words, it's wrong, but at least its the SAME wrongness the stock game is giving, and not a new wrongness kOS is adding.
You made the right call imho, KSP may (knock knock) eventually get fixed and in the meantime it's at least easy to troubleshoot stuff like this when the mod is using same numbers as the game itself.
